answers.answer: Hello, hope you are doing well.Many conditions can cause rise in levels of alkaline phosphatase.Liver problems, gall bladder problems, bone/skeletal problems and cancers all can cause rise in alkaline phosphatase.Few common causes related to liver and gall bladder are hepatitis,cholangitis,cirrhosis,fatty liver,cholecystitis etc.Vitamin D defficiency,fractured bone,osteomalacia,bone cancers are few other causes. A mildly elevated Alk phosp is usually seen in fatty liver since you have no other symptoms except pain in upper right quadrant and gas. In fatty liver there is fat in the liver, along with inflammation and damage. Fatty liver due to alcoholism is called Alcoholic fatty liver disease and the other one is Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, which is due to obesity, diabetes and high triglyceride levels. Consult your doctor for more queries and assistance. I hope it helps.Best wishes and regards!

question: I recently had a liver panel done as part of my yearly exam and my Alk Phos levels were elevated (normal a year ago).  I am scheduled for an abdominal ultrasound to rule out liver/gall bladder issues.  I have no significant symptoms...other than some intermittant upper right quadrant pain accompanied by tons of gas!  I do suffer from IBS (and had a colon re-section due to diverticular abcess 3 years ago).  I am constantly bloated and gassy.I have  read what elevated ALP could mean and some of it is very serious...and I'm anxious.  What readings would signify something serious?  Is a 199 reading considered moderate or significant?  All other readings were within nomal range.  No further bloodwork was suggested....just the ultrasound for now.bilateral hip replacementslumbar spinal stenosis, DDDcolon re-sectionno  alchoholThank you!
title: Elevated ALP (199) AST/ALT normal
